channel.title: The St. Louis Tennis Hall of Fame
channel.description: Celebrating the the deep roots of tennis in St. Louis - and vice versa.

wp:termmeta.wp:meta_value:
These organizations have made tennis their full-time focus.
From the clubs and parks where we play to the shops that keep us in gear, everything these Sustaining Partners do is vital to the health of the Hall of Fame and tennis players of every level, age and way of life.
The Hall and the Triple A Youth Foundation thank you for supporting them.

wp:category.wp:category_description: Great moments in the careers of our Hall of Fame champions and friends. Watch now!

wp:termmeta.wp:meta_value: Moments from the lives and careers of our Inductees: On video. In print. And touching the heart of anyone who's been a part of St. Louis tennis.

item.title: 2013: Jack Eggmann
item.dc:creator: marybaum
item.content:encoded: A founder of the Tennis Hall of Fame and then its chief scribe and historian, Jack wrote the book on our town's outsize contributions to the world of tennis – literally – when he published The Roots of Tennis: Blue Bloods to Blue Collars in 2008. Jack died in 2010. Here's Jack, at left, with Butch Bucholz at a tennis event sometime in the late 20th century.

item.title: 2013: Jane Pratt
item.dc:creator: marybaum
item.content:encoded: Jane Pratt gave a long life to local tennis, playing competitively and organizing events for adults and juniors. A Profile on the USTA Missouri Valley site describes her as a "crafty, solid doubles player on the court. In 1969 and 1976, Jane and Marilyn Mueller won the National Public Parks Senior Women’s doubles title. In 1976, they held the No. 1 national ranking in senior women’s doubles. Their success continued, as the duo won the women’s doubles title at the National Senior Olympics in 1993 and 1995." A teacher in the city of St. Louis her entire working life, Jane was a fixture around the tennis scene off the court as well. She worked tirelessly as the president of the Municipal Tennis Association for 43 years, until 2006, putting on tournaments and serving as the face of Dwight Davis Tennis Center. Jane died in 2009 of cancer, at 89.

item.title: 2013: Tom Fluri
item.dc:creator: marybaum
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_147" align="alignnone" width="1024"] Tom Fluri accepts his Hall of Fame induction on May 17, 2013.[/caption]
The current manager at Forest Lake Tennis Club, Tom had a big college playing career, as the Forest Lake website attests: A Big 8 doubles champion, he was ranked #1 in St. Louis singles and doubles and at Mizzou. He also did some damage as a local pro, consistently winning and making the finals of local tournaments and with gene dominating the local doubles scene through the 70s and into the early 1980s.

As a young pro.

1974 saw Tom and brother Gene Fluri winning the St. Louis District doubles title for the third time - they had done it two previous times as college players.

1975.

Tom won the Martin Kennedy singles and, again with Gene, won the doubles. He made the finals in the St. Louis District doubles and mixed doubles. Remember the old Tennis Press magazine? Tom and Gene ranked #1 in doubles that year.

 1976.

Tom won a fast-serve contest in St. Louis to qualify for the nationals at Forest Hills. He lost to Colin Dibley in New York. Won Martin Kennedy singles and with Gene, won the doubles. And he made the finals in the St. Louis district doubles again. At the KTVI Invitational, Tom:
  • Beat Juan Farrow in the final to win an AMC Pacer - a then-trendy new car.
  • With Gene, beat friendly rivals Heinbecker and Johnson to win the doubles title.
  • Won the mixed doubles with Nora Burst.
Won the McDonald’s Money Tournament singles title, beating Dino Martin in the quarters, Jorge Ramirez in semifinals and Jack Gorsuch in final and with Gene, won the doubles, beating Jack Gorsuch and Rich Flach in the final.

1977.

Tom won the Martin Kennedy singles title for a third time, and he and Gene made the doubles final. In the 80s, Tom and Gene won the All-Racquet Tournament all four years it was held. That means they won at tennis, table tennis, racquetball, squash, badminton and platform tennis.

College tennis.

1971.

After starting out on scholarship at the University of Kentucky, Tom transferred to Mizzou and played #1 singles, making the finals in the Big Eight. At #1 doubles with Gene, he brought home a Big Eight doubles title. Back home that summer, he made the singles finals at Dwight Davis and in the St. Louis District. In doubles, he and Gene won the Dwight Davis title and made the finals at the national ATA.

1972.

Junior year saw Tom playing #1 singles and amassing a 22-4 record, including a trip to the Big Eight finals. At #1 doubles with Gene, they made the finals in the Big Eight doubles as well, and came home to win the Muny doubles championship.

1973.

As a senior, Tom played No. 1 singles and doubles at Missouri, finishing with a singles record of 21-6, and made the finals in the Big Eight singles and doubles. He also broke Gene's Mizzou record for most career wins. Back home, he ranked No. 1 in Muny singles, won the Martin Kennedy singles title and made the finals in doubles.

Junior tennis.

1968.

Tom and Gene won the Missouri state doubles championship for McCluer High School and helped McCluer win the overall state title.

 1969.

With partner Bill Bristow, Tom won the Missouri state doubles title a second time, helping propel his school to a second state title. That year he would also rank #14 in the nation in junior doubles.

1970.

With Gene, Tom won the national ATA doubles. He ranked #1 in St. Louis in junior singles and doubles.

item.title: About the Hall of Fame
item.dc:creator: marybaum
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_72" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Triple A, now the Highlands, was the first home of the Hall.[/caption]

A little history.

Since its founding in 1990, 60 St. Louisans have been inducted into The St. Louis Tennis Hall of Fame for their contributions on and off the court. In April 2016, the Hall inducted five new tireless contributors to the game:
  • Craig Sandvig
  • Doug Smith
  • Pat Purcell
  • Ron Cobb
  • Terry Ward
Four deserving inductees – its principal archivist, the late Jack Eggman, the Fluri brothers and Jane Pratt – entered the Hall in 2013. Year after year, the Hall continues to recognize this area's rich tennis history. From Dwight Davis, founder of the Davis Cup, to former ATP executive director Butch Bucholz and Wimbledon champions Chuck McKinley and Ken Flach, St. Louis has left an indelible imprint on the game. Arthur Ashe once said that when he came here for his last year of high school in the early 1960s, St. Louis had more quality players than any other city outside greater Los Angeles. Now, our Hall of Fame shows the truth of his observations: just about every champion our town produced in those days - including Buchholz, McKinley, Justina Bricka, Carol Hanks Aucamp and Mary Ann Eisel Beattie - is in the Hall.

The Hall of Fame Festival.

A secondary goal for the Hall of Fame is to raise money for the Triple A Youth Foundation, a 501 (c) (3) educational organization that helps local juniors who want to succeed on the national and international stage. To that end, and thanks largely to Butch Buchholz, the Hall of Fame Festival has treated St. Louis to an entertaining mix of current and former greats. In the past, we've hosted Ashe, Rod Laver, Pancho Gonzalez, Billie Jean King, Trey Waltke, Doug and Ken Flach and Alex Olmedo. In 2013 and again in 2016, the Festival brought us Mats Wilander in an exhibition with Terry Ward and Stefan Kruger. after the final of the Frontenac Pro Doubles Classic. What a weekend!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I am interested in what information you have on Mr. Serrano and if you allow someone to come in and look through any records you may have. I am originally from Kirkwood and taught tennis at Tower Grove Park, Forest Park CC, Westchester, Concorde. I am a lifetime USTA member, PTR and USPTA member and a USRSA member. I have started collecting items with St. Louis ties. Rawlings racquets, Buchholz, Hart, McKinley, Eisel, Bricka, etc.... So basically I was hoping I could see anything you may have. Of course everything would be handled with the utmost care.

Scott,
I came across your post from 2015. Sorry for the late reply.
Can you contact me at terry@frctennis.com?
Terry Ward

item.title: 2013: Gene Fluri
item.dc:creator: marybaum
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_148" align="alignnone" width="1024"] Gene accepts his induction into the Hall.[/caption] Now an attorney in St. Louis County, Gene was the general manager at the old Town & Country Racquet Club from 1975 - 1992.But Gene had an amazing run as a high-school and college singles player, and with his brother, Tom, as a doubles champ as well.

Local pro highlights.

As a local pro, he and Tom racked up doubles championships throughout the 70s:
  • The Westwood Invitational in 1973.
  • The St. Louis District doubles title in 1974.
  • The Martin Kennedy doubles title in 1975.
  • Also in 1975: Remember the old Tennis Press? It ranked Gene and Tom #1 in doubles that year.

A big year: 1976.

That year Gene and Tom won:
  • The McDonald’s Money tournament doubles, beating Jack Gorsuch and Rick Flach in final.
  • The KTVI Invitational doubles tournament.
  • With other partners, Gene also won:
    • The St. Louis District Doubles.
    • The KTVI mixed doubles.

1977 and beyond.

Gene and Tom made the finals of the Martin Kennedy doubles tournament, and Gene won seven or eight mixed-doubles titles in the St. Louis District, Martin Kennedy and Dwight Davis tournaments - most with Barb Berger and then later with Vicki Mueller. In the 80s, Gene and Tom won the All-Racquet Tournament all four years it was held. That means they won at tennis, table tennis, racquetball, squash, badminton and platform tennis. As recently as 2008, Gene was still winning platform tennis matches.

College tennis.

As a freshman, Gene played #1 Singles at Mizzou and that year amassed a 17-7 record. Playing #1 singles as a sophomore, he finished with a 23-7 record. Playing #2 singles as a junior and senior, he would go on to break the University record for career singles wins, with 69. He played #1 doubles his whole career at Mizzou, winning the Big Eight doubles championship in 1971 with Tom and making the finals in 1972. Gene also won the St. Louis District  and Muny doubles titles as a college player.

McCluer High School.

Back in the Sixties, freshmen weren't elegible for varsity sports, so Gene's career started in his sophomore year. Then and as a junior, he payed #1 singles for McCluer. As a senior, and partnering with Tom, Gene won the Missouri state doubles championship and helped their team win the overall state championship.

item.title: Mission.
item.dc:creator: marybaum
item.content:encoded:
The mission of the St. Louis Tennis Hall of Fame is twofold:

1. To recognize this area's rich tennis history.

2. To raise funds to support the Triple A Youth Foundation, a 501 (c) (3)

educational organization that helps develop area juniors who want to pursue national and international competition.

item.title: Inductees from the 2000s.
item.dc:creator: marybaum
item.content:encoded:
Here's a list of Hall inductees from this millennium. [caption id="attachment_69" align="alignnone" width="614"] Maria Steinbach was one of the first inductees of the century.[/caption]

2006.

Leigh Strassner, Don Dippold and Lloyd Brown.

2003.

Ralph Hart, Dick Horwitz, Jerry Johnson and Bill Heinbecker.

2002.

Doug Flach and Gustave Boehmer, Jr.

2001.

Al Holtman, Harold Weise, Marilyn Mueller and Larry Miler.

2000.

Karl H. Hodge, Maria Rothschild Steinbach and Kim Steinmetz.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I think you should consider Art Stout for the St. Louis Tennis Hall of Fame. When he retired after 53 years he had the 3rd most wins of any high school coach in the country. He also served and help coach many great St. Louis players from Ken, Doug and Rick Flach, Bret Oberheide, Bob Curtis, Scott Bakula (the actor) up to Rachel Stuhlman who won the girls title 6-0, 6-0 in Art's last year as a coach.

item.title: Inductees from the 1990s.
item.dc:creator: marybaum
item.content:encoded:
Here are the inductees from the Hall's first decade. [caption id="attachment_72" align="alignnone" width="768"] Triple A, now the Highlands, was the first home of the Hall.[/caption]

1999.

Theodore Eggmann, Nancy Pearce Jeffett and Larry Parker.

1998.

Ken Flach.

1997.

Renee Blount, Roland M. Hoerr and C. Drummond Jones.

1996.

Allan Carvell, Helen Lewis, Poge Lewis and Robert McKinley.

1995.

Dick Johnson, Ward Parker and Howard Stephens, Jr.

1994.

Ed Serrano, Rod Susman and Frank Thompson.

1993.

Clifford Buchholz, Nina Hamilton and James Parker.

1992.

Richard Hudlin, William McChesney Martin and Trey Waltke.

1991.

Wray D. Brown, Early Buchholz, Sr., Corrina G. Chamberlain, Theodore Drewes, Sr. and Merceina Weiss Parker.

1990.

Carol Hanks Aucamp, Mary Ann Eisel Beattie, Justina Bricka, Earl Buchholz, Jr., Dwight F. Davis, Charles McKinley and Bill Price.

item.title: The Triple A Youth Foundation.
item.dc:creator: marybaum
item.content:encoded:
A 501 (c) (3) charitable educational organization, the Triple A Youth Foundation supports young players who want to pursue national and international competition. Your donations are tax-deductible; contact your tax advisor for full details. The Hall of Fame puts on events from time to time to support the Foundation.

The 2013 Hall of Fame Festival.

In 2013, the Hall of Fame Festival featured Mats Wilander's WOW exibition and the fifth annual Frontenac Doubles Classic.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: hi I have just recently received antique tennis rackets that are from early American times one is Wright and Ditson the other is Alice Marble just wondering if you have these rackets in your Hall of Fame displays or if you know collectors that might be interested in them I would hate for them to no be displayed Bob wright Bonne Terre mo.
Bob, you might want to get in touch with Terry Ward, terry@frctennis.com.

my father Robert S Weinstock passed away quickly and peacefully last week. I did not have time to contact you prior to putting info in the paper that included the family's preference for donations (in lieu of flowers) - indicating charity of their choice or Triple A Youth Foundation. I would asking for someone to call me to discuss how best to proceed with these donations. Rich Weinstock 314-993-2331 or 314-591-6397 (c) thanks

Rick,
I'm forwarding your note to Jay Jarvis and a few other folks, so they can get the word out - and be looking for donations.
Mary Baum Developer/site admin

item.title: May 17: Pratt, Eggmann enter Hall.
item.dc:creator: marybaum
item.content:encoded:
Two inductees entered the Hall of Fame posthumously: Jane Pratt and Jack Eggmann.

Jane Pratt.

Rick Randall told the crowd about how Jane ran all the tournaments at Dwight Davis with a loving but firm hand - and a sharp eye on the books. And the whole time, she kept up a championship-level doubles game of her own with her longtime partner, who was there to accept the award on Jane's behalf. [gallery link="file" type="slideshow" ids="151,150,149" orderby="rand"]

Jack Eggmann.

Tom O'Neill spoke lovingly about Jack Eggmann's role as the archivist of the Hall of Fame. Then he introduced Jack's daughter, who shared her own memories of growing up around tennis and the history of the game, seen through her father's eyes. [caption id="attachment_963" align="alignleft" width="298"] Tom O'Neill reads the citation inducting the late Jack Eggmann into the Hall of Fame to Jack's daughter.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_959" align="alignleft" width="298"] Jack Eggmann's daughter shares memories of life with the tennis archivist.[/caption]

item.title: Tom and Gene Fluri
item.dc:creator: marybaum
item.content:encoded: The St. Louis Tennis Hall of Fame inducted Tom and Gene Fluri for their outstanding contributions to the game as players at McCluer and Mizzou, and as young pros in St. Louis. These days, Tom is the manager at Forest Lake Tennis Club; Gene is a practicing attorney. [caption id="attachment_148" align="alignleft" width="1024"] Gene accepts his induction into the Hall.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_147" align="alignleft" width="1024"] Tom Fluri accepts his Hall of Fame induction on May 17, 2013.[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: […] deserving inductees – its principal archivist, the late Jack Eggman, the Fluri brothers and Jane Pratt – entered the Hall in […]

item.title: Pat Purcell.
item.dc:creator: marybaum
item.content:encoded:
[gallery type="square" size="large" ids="207,200,197,196,263"]

Pat: “My life in tennis has been a fulfilling journey.”

Starting in public parks, Pat Purcell first got the attention of the tennis community as a nationally ranked junior. In the 1980s, she became the top St. Louis women’s player. After college, Pat made tennis her business. She owned a club and, during and after, built one of the country’s biggest World Team Tennis programs. Now competing again after a 20-year break, Pat has won national titles in women’s 55 singles and doubles. Her U.S. Women’s 55 team won the Maureen Connelly Cup at the 2013 World Competition in Turkey. Pat is a pro in Chesterfield.

item.title: Doug Smith.
item.dc:creator: marybaum
item.content:encoded:
[gallery type="square" size="large" ids="213,214,212,260"]

Doug: “I’ve been blessed with the opportunity to turn an avocation into a vocation.”

Doug Smith came to St. Louis almost 40 years ago and built a strong junior program at Sunset, where he later became a part-owner. There he also developed and directed national-level tournaments – and coached Sunset players to 50 Top-10 Missouri Valley rankings. Later, as head coach at St. Joseph’s Academy, Doug guided the Angels to nine state championships in 18 years.

item.title: Terry Ward.
item.dc:creator: marybaum
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_226" align="alignnone" width="767"] Terry and Maria.[/caption]

Terry: “Tennis has always been such a big part of my life in St. Louis.”

At Frontenac since 1982 – as a teaching pro, tennis director and manager – Terry’s also been director of tennis at Old Warson Country Club since 1986. He played his college tennis at the University of San Diego, which is also when he played several pro events. In those, he was a finalist in singles and won four doubles titles. His best-ever world rankings were in the 300s. In the 1980s, Terry won multiple city championships and was the city’s top-ranked player. [gallery type="square" size="thumb" link="file" ids="226,227,225,224,209,264"]

item.title: Ron Cobb.
item.dc:creator: marybaum
item.content:encoded:
[gallery type="square" size="large" ids="243,245,244,211,261"]

Ron: “I’m thankful … for the good fortune I had to cover tennis during the sport’s boom years.”

Ron covered tennis in the ’70s at the Memphis Press-Scimitar and then at the St. Louis Post-Dispatch in the ’80s and ’90s, producing well over 700 articles on everything from junior tennis to city tournaments to professional tennis at the highest levels.

Cobb on the court.

Ron also played the game. He lettered at the University of Missouri, then later won four St. Louis District titles in the men’s 35s.

item.title: Craig Sandvig.
item.dc:creator: marybaum
item.content:encoded:
[gallery size="medium" type="square" ids="218,219,215,217,216"]

Craig: “Tennis has allowed me to spend time with incredible people … doing something I love.”

Craig’s been a huge part of St. Louis tennis for 45 years. With Doug Smith and a cast of many, he created a productive tennis learning center at Sunset. He’s coached every level of juniors and adults: state champions, sectional and nationally ranked players, college players, league winners – even the occasional beginner! Craig has also worked to grow the game: as a district officer, on sectional committees and on the board at Dwight Davis Tennis Center.

item.title: 1971: Eisel falls to newcomer Evert
item.dc:creator: marybaum
item.content:encoded:
Evert beats Inductee Mary Ann Eisel

Chris Evert was far from a household name the first time she won Wimbledon. On the path to her first title, Evert first had to get past St. Louisan and Inductee Mary Ann Eisel. Take a look! https://youtu.be/EXlhskYrEzM

item.title: Laver beats McKinley
item.dc:creator: marybaum
item.content:encoded:
After two trips to the Wimbledon finals, Rod Laver takes home the title on his third — beating St. Louisan and Hall-of-Famer Chuck McKinley in the process.
<iframe src="https://www.youtube-nocookie.com/embed/OR-Kz37xQPY?rel=0" width="560" height="315" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe>

item.title: Arthur Ashe memorial …
item.dc:creator: marybaum
item.content:encoded:
… is coming to Richmond Heights

Video highlights: Historical footage of Ashe playing and coaching. Plus, 2016 inductee Terry Ward takes us on a tour of the St. Louis Tennis Hall of Fame, now housed at String 'n Swing Tennis in Frontenac. Full article at Fox 2 News.

item.title: Sustaining Partners
item.dc:creator: marybaum
item.content:encoded:
These organizations have made tennis their full-time focus.

From the clubs and parks where we play to the shops that keep us in gear, everything these Sustaining Partners do is vital to the health of the Hall of Fame and tennis players of every level, age and way of life. The Hall and the Triple A Youth Foundation thank you for supporting them.
  • Chesterfield Athletic Club
  • Creve Coeur Racquet Club
  • Forest Lake Tennis Club
  • Frontenac Racquet Club
  • Kings Point
  • MAC West
  • Sunset Tennis Center
  • Vetta Concord
  • Woodsmill Tennis Club
Greenbriar Country Club Westwood CC Algonquin CC Bellerive CC Washington U Washington U Women St Louis U Men SLU Women UMSL Men UMSL Women Maryville Women Mo Bap Men Mo Bap Women Forest Hills CC Westborough Tower Grove Park Dwight Davis Clayton Shaw Park Old Warson CC St. Loouis Country Club Norwood Hills Country Club Whitmoor CC Sunset CC

item.title: Cliff Buchholz enters Colorado Hall
item.dc:creator: marybaum
item.content:encoded:
2011: Cliff Buchholz enters the Colorado Tennis Hall of Fame.

https://youtu.be/IEQwFIKqUGw

item.title: Creve Coeur Racquet Club
item.dc:creator: marybaum

item.title: Take your place in tennis history.
item.dc:creator: marybaum
item.content:encoded:
Become a member of the Hall of Fame right now.

When you buy tickets to an event or donate $25 or more, you become a Contributing Member of the Hall of Fame. You'll be supporting young players who aspire to compete on the national and international stage, and you'll be invited to the annual

annual Hall of Fame Festival dinner.

Your destiny awaits!

Join today – and save the evening of April 22 for a very special event. Details coming soon!
Donations may be tax-deductible via the Triple A Youth Foundation, a 501 (c) (3) educational organization.

item.title: The Highlands
item.dc:creator: marybaum
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_72" align="alignleft" width="1024"] Triple A, now the Highlands, was the first home of the Hall.[/caption]
